data.text: Is Bike Touring on an Electric Bike Possible?
Hi, apologies if this post is not allowed but I am wondering if anyone has long distanced toured on an electric bike? (Or considering it)? Pro's and Con's to it?
Yep, no problem as long as you stay in hotels/B&B/guesthouses. Sometimes direct charging on the bike and sometimes taking batteries into the room . I only Tour in Europe
data.author: Hans Ter Veer

data.text: You can also charge at campgrounds, it‚Äôs wild camping that‚Äôs out
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: Might be but when on a 20 days trip my accommodation spendings are 55‚Ç¨ a night on average, I prefer a real bed over an inflatable mattress.
data.author: Hans Ter Veer

data.text: You can charge your batteries directly from a solar panel using an MPPT boost charger. If you have a trailer, mount the panel on that. You won't be dependent on finding AC outlets to charge.
data.author: Bob Marshall

data.text: average rate for a basic motel in the US is about $90, campground is $25, it adds up over many weeks.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: Going on 45,000 MI. It is not rare that truck stops and Rural Gas Stations in the United States will allow you to plug in outside if you like. And many restaurants including fast food have Outlets inside.
data.author: James Mcginley

data.text: PS. I've had two catastrophic lithium ion battery fires, one burned down an apartment, and the other my prior rig. Lithium iron phosphate is what I use now, dramatically safer.
data.author: James Mcginley

data.text: that's good to know just in general. Would hate to burn my house down, charging it up
data.author: Gary Charlton

data.text: use only the most reliable professionally packaged cells, and still assume that they're going to explode and burn up on charging.

data.text: also more heavy and less energy dense i only use lithium ion phosphate in powerstation builds and such indoors dont use ebikes just becouse of that reason and im not the only to take the easy route even with bad health hate it when people go for ebike just to have it ez

data.text: but, meaning no disrespect, it is absolutely silly to think that e bikes necessarily make things easy. Generally I use it to make things harder, carrying me plus 20 40 60 100 lb. I'm a 70 year old stage 4 cancer survivor and this e-bike Rigg is my health plan.

data.text: If you are not physically disadvantaged why an E bike .All good touring bikes are low enough geared to make any ride a comfortable one .It is interesting the number of "young" riders opting for an "easy" ride but I guess that's the world today want easy.We are both 72yo still touring on real bikes .Of course e bike for disability assistance love seeing people maintaining their passion but not for the easy option .If that way inclined go moto much more reliable and practicle in remoter regions fuel is everywhere My personal opinion only.
data.author: Grant McKern

data.text: I'm just curious if anyone has toured on an electric bike, as the post states. I've a road bike and an off road bike, no electric bike in sight but doesn't mean I can't be curious if anyone has tried it.
data.author: Gary Charlton

data.text: There are a few who do this and they bring along extra batteries. One guy who has posted on a forum usually goes once a year and I think he takes 3 batteries and tries to stay at places with power--campgrounds and motels. Some hard core people actually have figured out how to pull a trailer with solar panels, but that's another set of tires to deal with and not good in winds. Ebike batteries can take a few hours to recharge. The Electric Bike Review forum has a section on touring and the Pacific Northwest tourer is on the forum as Mr Coffee.
data.author: Benjamin Tud

data.text: Why? Because I live in the mountains, had a low geared mountain bike but got tired of pushing it and wanted to go a bit farther. My ebike does not make all hills "easy". I've huffed and puffed my way up a forest road on it while in Turbo mode.
data.author: Benjamin Tud

data.text: thanks Benjamin
data.author: Gary Charlton

data.text: Oh, and the batteries are quite expensive. That's why I haven't bought an extra.
data.author: Benjamin Tud

data.text:
https://electricbikereview.com/forums/
Electric Bike Forums - Q&A, Help, Reviews and Maintenance
electricbikereview.com
data.author: Benjamin Tud

data.text: all bikes are "real bikes". In my view anything which encourages people to keep cycling is to be applauded. We should respect people's choices and not criticise them for it. There's enough disrespect of cyclists already without cyclists themselves adding to it.
data.author: Gordon Mason

data.text: I agree with Benjamin, drop the judgement. Any bike is a good bike! I am your age and I thoroughly enjoy riding ebike, belt drive bike, and Pedersen, different types of fun for different circumstances. I encourage everyone to get out and ride, full stop!
data.author: Raym Richards

data.text: Surely, touring is more about the journey and experience than the type of bike one does it on. Once had a crazy idea about touring on an electric Milk Float. They used to deliver the morning bottled milk years ago. Main issue is recharging ones batteries I think.
data.author: Boro Cav

data.text: so you went for the "easy" ride with all those gears, eh? If you are not physically disadvantaged, you should be touring on a fixie, like a real cyclist. My personal opinion only.
data.author: Allen Freeman

data.text: To be honest Allen I tour on my 13kg 48yo steel singlespeed 42/16 not as hard-core as you at least I can get "easy" coasting downhill lol .minimal bikepacking kit loaded all up weight 23kgs.Any hill I can't cope I walk it .Just another opinion of mine
data.author: Grant McKern

data.text: because it‚Äôs great fun and two people of different abilities can ride at the same pace.
data.author: Paula Lilburne

data.text: Interesting to see that Grant McKern hasn't commented. I wonder why.
data.author: Gordon Mason

data.text: I'm back Gordon. As I said my opinion .Love to see people pursuing their passion .My apologies touching a raw nerve .Each to his own I guess. A forum like this I would like people to weigh up thoughts and make their own decisions we don't all have to agree right or wrong .Enjoy your cycling whatever you ride as I enjoy mine .
data.author: Grant McKern

data.text: ridiculous. Ebikes are broad in power and capacity so to assume you would only use one for disability or to be lazy is nonsense. I can ride upwards of 60 miles in a single day and a ebike has made that journey not only significantly more tolerable but also reduced how long it takes. It's not so much lazy or me being disabled, it's just efficient use of modern day tech at your disposal and simple common sense. I could also always drive, but with rising running costs I'd rather not
data.author: Dean Hughes

data.text: yeah, but you shouldn‚Äôt be rude! Quite offensive what you said
data.author: Derrick Scott

data.text: yeah we should all go back to pen and paper as computers are ‚Äúcheating‚Äù - all new ideas are ‚Äúbad‚Äù
data.author: Derrick Scott

data.text: physically disadvantaged isn't black and white. Not linear. Befor I was disabled I had peaks and troughs pf low and high fitness. Having an ebike when I didn't have time to train would have extended my range for longer days in the saddle and tougher climbs.
data.author: Fern Hume

data.text: Yes, they are. My first was stolen, the insurance didn't only pay 75% of the price, even it was only a week old. My spare battery I will get soon is sponsered. My sponsor is so impressed that I (70+ y-o) will go from Sweden to Egypt.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: A lot of people think we don't need to pedal, when we ride an e-bike ü§î
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: And some of those people do not see an ebike as a 'real bike', snobs. Unfortunately there is snobbery in every group of people. Ho hum!
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I now do touring on an electric bike and love it. I used to be limited to river valley routes - no more! You have to be confident about range - I take a spare battery. I try and travel light - the extra weight of the ebike can make things rather heavy. It's easy to take your bike on a ferry - flying isn't permitted. Go for it!
data.author: Evan Giles

data.text: I just can't understand why some feel they have to judge others because they choose to go the ebike route. Just chill my friend!
data.author: Evan Giles

data.text: I think Amtrak forbids ebikes also.
data.author: Benjamin Tud

data.text: they only have a 50 lb weight limit last I checked.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: In Europe you can take your e-bike on all the trains where you can take your bike. Best to handle though on regional trains.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: I have now taken my bike on Amtrak half a dozen times in the last three years. Pop the battery off and it‚Äôs not an issue. I‚Äôm headed to Colorado and then on to Ohio/Pennsylvania next month with my E. Amtrak all the way.
data.author: Mike McAuley

data.text: And the usual ebike ignorance shows up. Folks maybe ought to do more research before making comments.
data.author: Benjamin Tud

data.text: Quite right. I'm 70 and rather than easy vs hard, an ebike makes possible what would have previously been impossible for me. The increase in range not only opens up more touring options, it also makes the experience more enjoyable. (I've never been a serious 'lycra-cyclist')!
data.author: Gary Dye

data.text: 'Zactly. I've just come back with my ebike loaded down with groceries. It's good for errands and it is good for fun--just riding around. I'm also not a lycra style cyclist.

data.text: I did a 2400 mile tour on one last summer. You will need at least 2 big batteries, plus some time to recharge on long mileage days.

data.text: Apologies not accepted!

data.text: Iam on a trip right now, Holland Towards Spain 2300km full gear icl tent and gas cooking. I ride max 150km a day i use 2 x650wh Bosch batterys And a quick charger. Distance depands how many hills you have to take. From campsite to campsite , but next week bad weather forecast üò¨ I need to charge approx every 200km . Its good fun .
data.author: Stefan Van Zurk

data.text: Something to take into account is where you're touring from and to. If you are doing a loop from home or transporting via car ok. You can't fly with the batteries, even when fitted to the bike. E-bikes are generally heavier than their non-E counterparts and are more difficult to transport.
data.author: Randall Treloyn

data.text: correct, you must ground ship your batteries separately, or use a bike shipping service that handles ebikes. Going overseas with an ebike isn‚Äôt possible.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: bike Friday claim you can fly with their batteries as each cell disconnects from each other and so none exceed the maximum allowed value
data.author: Derrick Scott

data.text: thought you can rent batteries in Europe?
data.author: Derrick Scott

data.text: Perhaps, but it would probably be expensive for a long tour.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: I think it isn't easy to find the same kind of battery you need for your e-bike. I live in Sweden and have a Sweden made e-bike. Even the battery is imported of the factory, I can't get such a battery in e.g. Germany.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: How should that be possible?
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: I'm not sure the airlines would agree with that. It is certainly possible to ship batteries via land/sea. All of these are simply things to consider. My original comment didn't say E-bike touring wasn't possible, it was just to highlight some things a potential E-bike tourer might consider when making that decision.
data.author: Randall Treloyn

data.text: contact Bike Friday?!
data.author: Derrick Scott

data.text: Never trust a manufacturer or seller when it comes to legality or suitability. Do your own research. Every trip will be different.
data.author: Randall Treloyn

data.text: of course- but BF based in Eugene, OR May gave a good idea of which airlines do allow their batteries- they mention this on their web page do have a vested interest in backing that up, so would be a good place to start the research
data.author: Derrick Scott

data.text: I bought an e-bike for commuting but used it last summer for holiday as well. And I loved it ! I cycled from Holland (home) to the Garmisch-Partenkirchen in southern Germany and then to the Schwarzwald. I enjoyed it very much. This summer there surely will be another e-bike-holiday.
data.author: Rob Ruijs

data.text: One thing that I was curious of is how easy it was to charge your battery. In Germany there were quite a few public charge-stations in towns and villages. And you can always ask at a restaurant or caf√© .
data.author: Rob Ruijs

data.text: bring several batteries
data.author: Sean Z Smith

data.text: Add solar
data.author: Sean Z Smith

data.text: only in very small towns can it be a challenge to find an outlet. Often public parks have pavilions with working outlets, but sometimes they are turned off, so then I had to spend extra time riding around just looking for a place to plug in. I use two chargers, one for each battery.
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: watch "long way up< 2 guys rode form the bottom of south america to Ca on electric harleys> theres a few people i see here saying their going to bicycle the same route< seems like it would be a pain in the ass and unnecessary hassles finding somewhere to charge ur bike
data.author: Richard Reitman

data.text: In most countries, it should be feasible, unless you go off grid. I have a similar charging issue, but not as intense as using an ebike. The first step that I would consider for an ebike would be to carry an additional battery and/or limit your daily mileage. If you get an additional battery or two, and don't forget to carry additional chargers. I have a medical device that can run for 3 nights, max, using a large battery bank. In the past I stayed in cheap hotels, but that worked out more expensive than I would like. In future I plan to wild camp but spend every third or fourth night in a cheap hotel, or couch surfing, as well as charging where I can on the road. I am also considering a 28W solar panel/and or dynamo to augment other charging methods.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I have read that people manage with large solar setups on trailers that can continuously wild camp
data.author: Derrick Scott

data.text: I met a couple riding an electrified tandem on the Oregon coast last year. They were towing a trailer with a solar panel on top to charge their spare battery. They also used outlets when available so they could have both batteries fully charged. They said that they only used the battery when they felt the need - up long &/or steeper hills and for headwinds.
data.author: Roger Noehren

data.text: How can I charge an e-bike battery by solar? The charger is for ~220V
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: Believe me, there is a way, but I'm not an electrician and it involves inverters, I think and other stuff.
data.author: Benjamin Tud

data.text: OK, sounds too complicated for me
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: Yup. Me too. I would just break down and buy an extra battery and charger.
data.author: Benjamin Tud

data.text: Yeah it's fun
data.author: Sean Z Smith

data.text: The only time e-bikes tend to annoy me is when they pass me close without warning when I'm chugging up a steep one. Or basically anytime they pass without a horn toot or some other heads up.
data.author: Richard Roussy
Merlin RsMndz

data.text: See above.
data.author: Robert Fletcher

data.text: Did 17,800 km half a lap round Australia. Took 3 500wh batteries each and a large solar panel to make sure we could travel the 300 km between power points. Pros - Great fun.Could carry heaps of water, food chairs etc. as pulling trailers. Able to travel as the same speed as my companion. Headwind/hills just means you charge up more often. Cons if the motor breaks down you will need to transport bike to get it repaired. In our case the Bosch motor needed to be sent halfway around Australia to get replaced. This caused a lengthy delay to our trip particularly during lock down. Spent more money on camping than we would have liked in order to charge up. Towing a solar panel means you carnt enter some bike paths. Enjoy your travels Gary
data.author: Paula Lilburne

data.text: that sounds like a great adventure, but I think solar panel is not needed if you can keep distances under 150 km between charges
data.author: Kris Siejko

data.text: I‚Äôd reckon you‚Äôd be correct with that. Unfortunately parts of Australia are really desolate. I wouldn‚Äôt bother with a solar panel in Europe or SE Asia.
data.author: Paula Lilburne

data.text: My e-bike battery make 80 kms as the most, even when it's not very hilly. It's a 400 something. I can't get a bigger one for my bike. 150 kms sounds very much, the battery must be hugh and heavy.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: Which solar panel did you use? Do you have Brand and model?
data.author: Johnnie Walker

data.text: Only cons really
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: I've been ebiking since 2011 and own several ebikes. I would never dream of touring on an ebike. Ebikes are short distance commuter vehicles and touring bike set ups should be light and simple.
data.author: Ryan Jeambey

data.text: yep... Don't rely on that battery especially if heavy. Won't last on a pull...
data.author: Robert Umpenhour
Maxwell Seward Young

data.text: Battery vs Burro üò≥
data.author: Mike Ha

data.text: i was due to leave a couple of weeks back for Northern Spain with my EMTB to ride some 2000 miles round trip to Morocco unfortunately i got hit with Covid and only just a week back tested Negative i am still having problems breathing properly, in part due to my age 72 i do have 2 x Shimano 8010 batteries and 2 chargers total range of 120 miles max ... i am seriously considering downgrading my ride to maybe 1000 miles now through Ireland reason being it would be a pig of an adventure sitting in a traffic jam of some 20 miles trying to get to Dover Docks..with the car. The Spanish Ride had been in the planning for 2 years with my bike.... i should have added 50 years of smoking doesn't help either but Covid certainly screwed my breathing..charging my batteries won't be an issue either there are nice hotels for my added comfort.
data.author: Raymond Stevens

data.text: I use a specialised ebike in the mountain in cape town now and get far more enjoyment than when i used to strain my heart and body racing uphill but in London where i part live and tour i use a merida hardtail for long distance. But glory of the ebike is my wife now has a Giant liv ebike in London and will be joining me for the first time this summer while i use the peddle bike and everyone is happy.....
data.author: Guy Florin

data.text: It‚Äôs a great idea, and you should be super welcomed into the fellowship. I suspect charging might be an issue in some locations, but how about working a way to do it by heat and solar?
data.author: Nigel Clark

data.text: I'm riding an e-bike, made 2500 km last year, will make much more this year. Had actually no bigger problems to charge, but I do mostly warmshowers, some times couchsurfing and if I don't find any host, hostels or cheap hotels etc. The problem is that one battery not always is enough for one day. In that cases I charged at gas stations or in a caf√©, but it takes almost two hours for going 20 km further. Though this year I'll have a spare battery with me.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: do you feel guilty charging on their electric and not contributing to them ?
data.author: Karl Clark

data.text: I pay if they ask for it. Nobody has asked so far. At gas stations and caf√©s I always ask what I have to pay for charging my battery, nobody wanted money so far, but I feel, that I have to buy/eat food at that places and do it. By the way, I think the "amount of electricity" for charging is very low.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: At the average kilowatt hour pricing in the US, it‚Äôs usually well under a dollar and more often around $.35-$.50 to charge a 500Wh battery.Ôøº
data.author: Mike McAuley

data.text: I spend days between power-points. I couldn't imagine being reliant on the grid or having my schedule be dictated by "urbanization". I stop where I want and go where I please for as long as I desire. Packing a weeks-worth of food allows for this.
data.author: Benjamin Moravec

data.text: Two batteries, two chargers and you have to avoid flying. It is simple as long as you stay indoor at night. Actually with two batteries you can sleep at tent every other night if you travel bit less than 100km per day. I use both ebike and normal bike with my trips. It really does not matter if your trip is 200km or 2000km. When it is 20000km you should be still ok with batteries surviving the task.
data.author: Jenni Kylm√§koski

data.text: I have done a number of long distance solo tours on ebikes. My list. 1100 km 2 week tour in Germany. 2 week 950 km ruta de plata in Spain, 10 days circle of Mallorca and 650 km. 1300 km 3 week your of Costa Rica. 3 two week tours of 1000 km in Alberta. Alberta tours I had two batteries, rest one battery. Only on a few occasions did I charge at restaurants during lunch. One hour lunch charge only adds about 10 k in range. My routes are planned so that I have a hotel about 100 or so km. My next ebike journey will be 13,500 over 5 months from North Pole Alaska to Panama City, Panama. However this one will be fully supported.
data.author: Robert Fletcher

data.text: a question. Wath is the km/h average?
data.author: Merlin RsMndz

data.text: when I ride whether it is on an ebike or my other bikes I ride at 24 k/h. That is a comfortable pace that I can do for 6 hours. I don't have a throttle.
data.author: Robert Fletcher

data.text: Do a search on You Tube. I have found a few people who have used ebikes for long distance trips. Sounds like a great idea.
